title: Erroneous continuous cardiac output by calibrated pulse contour analysis
abstract: Pulse contour analysis techniques are used for beat-to-beat tracking of cardiac output in critically ill patients. However, an adequate pulse pressure waveform signal and identification of the appropriate (i.e. systolic) part of the waveform by the monitor are crucial for correct calculation of continuous cardiac output. We observed a case where the monitor failed to correctly identify the systolic part of the waveform during tachycardia thus giving false readings. We would like to emphasize the importance of visually checking the waveform for any irregularities that may cause erroneous calculations before initiating a therapy based on these values. One advantage of the system used here is that the part of the pressure curve used for analysis is automatically indicated.

motivations: Pulse contour analysis techniques can provide erroneous continuous cardiac output readings if the pulse pressure waveform signal is inadequate or misinterpreted.
Incorrect identification of the systolic part of the waveform can lead to false readings, potentially impacting therapy decisions.
objectives: Highlight the importance of visually inspecting the waveform for irregularities before relying on continuous cardiac output calculations.
Emphasize the need for accurate identification of the systolic part of the waveform for correct calculations.
methods: Use of pulse contour analysis techniques for beat-to-beat tracking of cardiac output.
Visual inspection of the waveform for irregularities.
results: Recognition of the potential for erroneous continuous cardiac output readings using pulse contour analysis.
Importance of verifying waveform accuracy before initiating therapy based on calculated values.
llama_json.research_subject: Accuracy of continuous cardiac output calculations using pulse contour analysis

motivations: Pulse contour analysis techniques, while useful, can sometimes fail to correctly identify crucial parts of the waveform, leading to false readings.
There is a need to ensure the accuracy of continuous cardiac output calculations before initiating therapy based on these values.
objectives: Highlight a case where the monitor failed to correctly identify the systolic part of the waveform during tachycardia.
Emphasize the importance of visually checking the waveform for any irregularities that may cause erroneous calculations.
methods: Use of a case study where the monitor failed to correctly identify the systolic part of the waveform during tachycardia.
results: Revealed the potential for false readings in pulse contour analysis techniques due to failure in correctly identifying the systolic part of the waveform.
Highlighted the importance of visual checks to prevent erroneous calculations.
openai_json.research_subject: Investigation of errors in continuous cardiac output calculation by pulse contour analysis

motivations: Pulse contour analysis techniques require accurate identification of the systolic part of the waveform for correct cardiac output calculation, but monitors can fail to properly identify this during certain conditions like tachycardia.
Erroneous cardiac output readings from automated monitoring systems can lead to inappropriate clinical decisions in critically ill patients.
objectives: Report a case where pulse contour analysis monitoring failed to correctly identify the systolic waveform during tachycardia, resulting in false cardiac output readings.
Emphasize the importance of visual verification of waveform analysis before making clinical decisions based on automated cardiac output measurements.
methods: Clinical observation and documentation of a case where calibrated pulse contour analysis provided erroneous cardiac output measurements during patient tachycardia.
results: The monitoring system failed to correctly identify the systolic portion of the waveform during tachycardia, leading to false cardiac output readings.
Visual inspection of the waveform and the automatically indicated analysis segment can help clinicians identify potential errors before initiating therapy.
anthropic_json.research_subject: Accuracy of calibrated pulse contour analysis for cardiac output monitoring
